newsitem.title: USA: Japan faces serious financial strains - Summers.
newsitem.headline: Japan faces serious financial strains - Summers.

text.p: Japan faces profound economic challenges and needs to pursue a policy of domestic demand-led growth, U.S. Deputy Treasury Secretary Lawrence Summers said on Wednesday.
Among those challenges, he told the Economic Strategy Institute, were "very, very serious financial strains," an aging population, and an economy overburdened by regulation.
"The Japanese economy faces profound challenges," he said.
Summers argued that the best way for Japan to overcome these problems was through an economic "expansion led from within."

"That is crucial in order to avoid a recurrence of the kind of strains that existed at some points in the past," he said, in apparent reference to Tokyo's past friction with its trading partners, including the United States.
Summers spent much of his speech at the dinner meeting arguing that the United States had much to gain and little to fear from economic globalization.
With U.S. trade barriers already very low, the United States stands to benefit from entry into barrier-reducing trade pacts with foreign countries, he said.
Where trade pacts are violated, the United States will react strongly, he said.
He said that what he called the "continued seriousness" of the U.S. trade deficit showed the critical importance of bringing down trade barriers overseas.
He also noted that increased U.S. savings would help reduce the trade deficit.
"We've made some progress (in increasing savings) but we need to do a lot more," he said.
